form_image.choose_source: Where do you want the image from?

delete_confirmation.title: Delete {{type}}?
delete_confirmation.message: Are you sure you want to delete "{{name}}"? This action cannot be undone.

unsaved_changes.title: Discard changes?
unsaved_changes.description: You have unsaved changes. If you leave now, all changes will be lost.

how_to_start.title: How to Start Your Book
how_to_start.description: Discover your writing style and take the first step in your creative journey

creative_block.title: Overcoming Creative Block
creative_block.description: Practical exercises to unlock your creativity and get back to writing

creating_characters.title: Creating Memorable Characters
creating_characters.description: From initial idea to complete profile: build characters your readers will love

building_world.title: Building Your World
building_world.description: Techniques to create convincing regions, cultures, and hierarchies

power_system.title: Creating a Power System
power_system.description: Organize and explain your story's magic or power system in a visual and didactic way

fast_writing.title: Fast and Efficient Writing
fast_writing.description: Learn to plan the bare minimum and start writing quickly using arcs and references

using_logs.title: Log System
using_logs.description: Learn to use logs to record important events in your story and entities for future reference

how_to_start.main_subtitle: Discover your writing style and find the perfect path to bring your story to life
how_to_start.intro: There's an old dilemma in the world of creative writing: are you a <1>gardener</1> or an <3>architect</3>? Understanding your style not only makes it easier to begin your journey, but also helps you embrace your strengths and work on your limitations.

gardener.title: The Gardener Writer
gardener.description: Like a gardener who plants seeds and watches them grow, you write by discovering the story as it unfolds. Your characters and plots reveal themselves during the writing process.

strengths.discovery: Discovery is part of the fun

challenges.lost: Risk of getting lost along the way

gardener.how_to_start_title: How to Start as a Gardener

how_to_start.write: Write your chapters freely, without overthinking at the moment. Leave improvements for later
how_to_start.characters: Create characters as they appear in your writing
how_to_start.annotations: Use annotations and links to track emerging ideas
how_to_start.dashboard: Visit the Dashboard when you feel the need to organize

architect.title: The Architect Writer
architect.description: Like an architect who draws blueprints before building, you plan every detail of your story. Your foundations are solid and every word has its defined purpose.
architect.how_to_start_title: How to Start as an Architect

how_to_start.premise: Define the premise and goals of your story
how_to_start.characters: Create complete characters with archetypes and backgrounds
how_to_start.world: Build the world with hierarchies and locations
how_to_start.plot: Map plot arcs with clear events and structure

balance.title: The Truth: You Can Be Both
balance.description: Most successful writers dance between both worlds. Some chapters sprout freely like wild gardens. Others follow meticulous blueprints. The secret isn't choosing a side, but discovering <1>when to use each approach</1>.
balance.step1_description: Write your chapters freely, letting the story flow. Use <1>editor annotations</1> or <3>draft chapters</3> to save creative ideas ‚Äî from small notes to entire chapters that may be useful in the future.
balance.step2_description: After <1>10 to 20 chapters</1>, pause to review what you've written. This is the moment to put on your architect hat.
balance.step3_description: Structure characters, locations, and plot arcs. While organizing, let your <1>imagination flow</1> ‚Äî create interesting future plots that can have foreshadowing from the beginning.
balance.step4_description: With a clearer structure, return to gardener mode and continue your creative journey, now with greater awareness of the whole.

power_system.main_subtitle: Use our visual tool to create a clear and organized magic or power system for your story
power_system.intro: Every fantasy world needs rules. Whether it's a complex magic system, mystical martial arts, or superpowers, the key is to <1>organize and communicate</1> those rules clearly. Our Power System tool was created for this.

basics.title: Basic and General Concepts
basics.description: Use dedicated pages to explain the fundamentals of your system. Ideal for general rules, universal laws, and concepts everyone needs to understand.

strengths.fundamentals: Fundamentals and universal laws of the system

basics.example: Create a 'Magic Fundamentals' page explaining where mana comes from, how everyone accesses it, and the three universal laws governing its use.

abilities.title: Specific Abilities
abilities.description: Create organized folders for individual abilities. The differentiator: you can <1>link each ability to specific characters</1>, visually showing who masters what.

strengths.folders: Folders by category (Fire, Healing, Illusion, etc)
strengths.visual: Clear visualization of who has each power

abilities.example: Create a 'Fire Spells' folder. Inside it, pages for 'Fireball', 'Flame Shield', 'Phoenix'. Link 'Fireball' to the character 'Arkan, the Pyromancer'.

advanced.title: Advanced Concepts
advanced.description: Reserve pages for complex mechanics, secret techniques, or aspects of the system that few master. Perfect for plot points and future revelations.
advanced.example: Create 'Ancestral Magic' with informative blocks about lost techniques. Use attribute blocks to show difficulty and danger levels.

organization.title: How to Organize Your System
organization.step1_description: Start with <1>1-2 pages of general concepts</1>. Use paragraph blocks to explain, lists for rules, and informative blocks for important warnings.
organization.step2_description: Create <1>folders for each type/school</1> of power. Inside them, one page per specific ability. Use image and icon blocks to make it visual.
organization.step3_description: For each ability, use the <1>'Manage Links'</1> button to connect to characters who master it. This creates a visual network of who can do what.
organization.step4_description: Create advanced pages as the story progresses. Use <1>navigator blocks</1> to create links between related concepts, forming an interactive wiki.

blocks.title: Blocks: Your Visual Tools
blocks.description: 16 types of blocks transform text into visual and organized content:

visual_blocks.icon: Circular icon with title and description
visual_blocks.icon_group: Grid of up to 4 icons per row

examples.visual_demo_subtitle: In this guide, we'll explore step by step how to structure a complete magic system. You'll learn to organize pages, create detailed abilities, link to characters, and navigate between pages. Let's use an Elemental Magic System with fire, healing, and more as an example!
examples.page_base_description: The base page contains general concepts of the system. Use simple blocks to explain universal rules, energy costs, etc.
examples.page_base_example_text: Magic is the ability to manipulate elemental energy from the world around you. Each mage needs mana to cast spells.
examples.ability_page_description: Now we create a specific ability within the 'Fire Spells' folder. Here you can use all types of blocks to detail the ability: description, power attributes, users, tags, and more!
examples.ability_benefits_title: Why create pages for each ability?

ability_benefits.character_link: Direct character link: Automatically connect the ability to the character profile
ability_benefits.visual_detail: Visual detailing: Use attribute bars, icons, and images to explain visually
ability_benefits.folder_organization: Folder organization: Group by element, type, or rarity
ability_benefits.smart_navigation: Smart navigation: Create links between related abilities

examples.ability_example_text: Fireball is one of the most basic and essential elemental spells in any fire mage's arsenal. It consists of conjuring a flaming sphere that can be thrown at enemies.
examples.navigation_description: Use the Navigator block to create links between related pages. For example, at the end of the 'Fireball' page, you can link to 'Flame Shield' (another fire spell).
examples.navigation_tip: üí° When clicked, the user is taken directly to the 'Flame Shield' page
examples.character_linking_description: You can link entire pages or specific sections of your power system to characters! When you do this, the link automatically appears on the character profile, making navigation easier.

character_linking_difference.page: Entire page: Clicking the tag opens the entire 'Fireball' page. The default name will be 'Fireball'.
character_linking_difference.section: Specific section: Clicking opens only that section (e.g., just 'Description'). The default name will be the section name, regardless of how many sections the page has.

examples.character_profile_title: How it looks on the character profile:
examples.customizing_label_description: You can give a custom label to make it clearer. For example, instead of showing 'Fireball', it can show 'Main Magic' or 'Fire Specialty'.
examples.customizing_label_how_description: Click the edit button in the upper right corner of the character page:
examples.customizing_label_edit_tip: ‚Üë Click the pencil button (circled in red) to enter edit mode
examples.customizing_label_edit_mode: After entering edit mode, linked powers will have edit and delete buttons:
examples.customizing_label_edit_power_tip: ‚Üë Click the pencil icon (circled in red) next to the power to edit its custom label
examples.conclusion_description: Now you know how to create complete power systems: organize pages in folders, detail abilities with various blocks, link to characters, and navigate between pages. Use your creativity to create amazing systems! ‚ú®

fast_writing.main_subtitle: Learn the technique of writing quickly by creating only what's necessary and reviewing every 10 chapters
fast_writing.intro: The best way to write is by <1>writing</1>. Many authors spend months planning without writing a single word. This technique teaches you to <3>plan the bare minimum</3> and start writing as quickly as possible, using 10-chapter cycles.

step1.title: Step 1: Create Your First Arc
step1.description: Before writing, go to the Plot tab and create an arc using the arc detail features. List what you expect in this first block of chapters.
step1.why_description: The arc serves as your <1>compass</1>. You don't need to put everything in at that moment - you can keep changing it over time as you write. Just enough to know the general direction of the next chapters.
step1.what_include_title: What to include in the arc:

what_include.goal: Main objective of this block of chapters
what_include.outcome: How you want this block to end
what_include.key_events: Key events you have in mind at that moment

step1.tip: Don't worry about perfection! The arc is a guide, not a prison. You can adjust it as you write.

step2.title: Step 2: Write 10 Chapters
step2.description: Now it's time to <1>write</1>. Focus on producing content, not perfection. Use the app's tools to help you.

features.arc_reference: View the arc while writing to stay on track
features.entity_links: Create characters, locations, and items as they're mentioned
features.quick_notes: Use editor annotations for ideas that come up
features.references: Use the References feature to quickly consult data while writing

step2.writing_tip: Write in <1>focused sessions</1>. Better to write 500 words per day for 10 days than try to write 5000 words at once.

step3.title: Step 3: Review Every 10 Chapters
step3.description: After writing 10 chapters, <1>stop and review</1>. This is the moment to become the architect.

review_checklist.arc_alignment: Did the chapters follow the arc you created?
review_checklist.consistency: Are there character or plot inconsistencies?
review_checklist.opportunities: Did plot opportunities arise that you can explore?

after_review.update_entities: Update character sheets, items, factions, and other mentioned data
after_review.create_next_arc: Create the next arc based on what happened
after_review.fix_inconsistencies: Fix small inconsistencies (big ones can wait)
after_review.note_future_plots: Note future plot ideas in the Dashboard

cycle.title: The 10-Chapter Cycle
cycle.description: Repeat this cycle until you finish your book. With each cycle you learn more about your story and characters.

benefits.less_planning: Less time planning, more time writing
benefits.flexibility: Flexibility to explore ideas that arise

tips.title: Advanced Tips
tips.tip1: Use the editor's References feature to quickly consult characters, locations, and other data while writing, without losing focus.
tips.tip2: Editing comes later. In gardener mode (first 10 chapters), focus only on <1>producing content</1>.
tips.tip3: Each completed 10-chapter cycle is a victory. You're <1>making progress</1>, not just planning.
tips.tip4: 10 chapters is a suggestion. If you prefer to review every 5 or 15, adjust to what works for you.

using_logs.main_subtitle: Use logs to record events, changes, and milestones of your story and entities
using_logs.intro: During writing, many important details happen: a character reveals a secret, a prophecy is mentioned, an important change occurs. The <1>Log System</1> helps you <3>document and find</3> these moments quickly.

types.title: Log Types
types.description: Each log needs to be classified into one of three types of importance:

hook.title: Hook
hook.description: Events that generate expectation or pull the narrative forward. Ex: A character makes an important promise.

lore.title: Lore
lore.description: Background information about the world, history, or concepts. Ex: Explanation of how magic works.

foreshadowing.title: Foreshadowing
foreshadowing.description: Subtle anticipations of future events. Ex: An object mentioned that will be important later.

global_logs.title: Global Logs
global_logs.subtitle: Accessible via the icon at the top of the Dashboard
global_logs.description: The <1>Global Logs</1> are the heart of the system. Here you can see all the important events of your book in one place.

features.create: Create new logs with type, moment, and description
features.link: Link a log to multiple entities (characters, factions, items, races, regions)
features.search: Search logs by name or description
features.filter: Filter by log type or moment

global_logs.use_case: Use global logs when an event involves multiple entities or when you want to have an overview of all important events.

local_logs.title: Entity Local Logs
local_logs.subtitle: Accessible via the 'Logs' button in each entity's detail
local_logs.description: In addition to global logs, each entity (character, faction, etc) has its own <1>logs view</1> showing only events linked to it.
local_logs.example_description: When opening a character's details and clicking 'Logs', you'll see only logs linked to that character.

features.edit: Edit log (if linked only to this entity)
features.reorder: Reorder in the order that makes sense for that entity

local_logs.restriction: If a log is linked to multiple entities, you cannot edit it from the local view. Use 'Global Logs' to edit.

step1.title: While writing
step1.description: When something important happens, quickly create a log noting the type, chapter, and a brief description.

step2.title: Link to entities
step2.description: Then, link the log to the involved entities (characters, locations, factions, etc).

step3.title: Consult when needed
step3.description: Use search and filters to quickly find information. Access from the global or local view of each entity.

tips.title: Usage Tips
tips.tip1: Short and direct descriptions work best. You can always add more details later.
tips.tip2: Mark as <1>Hook</1> events you need to resolve, <1>Lore</1> for world information, and <1>Foreshadowing</1> for clues you've planted.
tips.tip3: Every few chapters, review your logs to not forget to resolve pending hooks or use foreshadowing you've planted.
tips.tip4: Use logs for events and important changes. Use editor notes for loose ideas and drafts.
